headline: Chef John's Roasted Butternut Squash Soup
description: Roasting the vegetables first brings deep, rich flavor to this sage-brown butter butternut squash soup--perfect for a chilly fall day.

video.description: Watch how to make a comforting bowl of flavorful butternut squash soup.
video.name: Chef John's Roasted Butternut Squash Soup

name: Chef John's Roasted Butternut Squash Soup
recipeIngredient: 2 teaspoons kosher salt, or to taste - divided
1 (3 1/2) pound butternut squash, halved lengthwise and seeded
6 cups chicken broth, plus more if needed

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).

Drizzle olive oil into large roasting pan. Add onion, carrots, garlic cloves, and a pinch of salt. Toss until coated in oil. Place squash halves flesh side up on the chopped vegetables. Sprinkle squash with additional salt.
Roast in preheated oven until squash is tender and easily pierced with the tip of a knife, about 1 hour. Allow vegetables to cool a bit.

Melt butter over medium heat. Butter will foam, and start to turn a golden brown. Reduce heat to low. When butter turns from golden to a light, nutty brown, remove pan from heat and immediately add sage leaves. Stir to infuse the butter with sage.

Scoop out squash flesh and place in roasting pan with roasted chopped vegetables. Transfer mixture into large stock pot. Stir in chicken broth, brown sage butter, and maple syrup. Place pot over high heat and bring to a simmer. Reduce heat to low; slowly simmer to blend flavors, 45 to 60 minutes. Remove from heat.
Blend until very smooth with an immersion blender, 3 or 4 minutes. Pass mixture through a strainer to remove any remaining fibrous bits.

If soup seems too thick, add a few tablespoons of water or chicken broth. Stir in apple cider vinegar, a pinch of salt (or to taste), and cayenne pepper. Garnish servings of soup with a dollop of creme fraiche and chopped chives.

review.reviewBody: Sounds delicious, can’t wait to try it

Made this as written by Chef John and it was delicious. Next time I will make the brown butter and fry the sage in the stock pot to avoid having to clean an extra pan (since it will be transferred there anyway).

delicious. mine was definitely too thick so I added more stock. I also took out the sage leaves as the recipe didn't specify, but see now that I was supposed to leave them in after letting them soak for awhile. I thought it was okay until I added the apple cider vinegar. The vinegar made it. I did add a cut up apple to the roasting but otherwise followed the recipe. My mom likes a bit of brandy instead of the vinegar
A great tasting soup, we used balsamic vinegar Instead of apple cider
Adding 3 stars to this. Mainly due to the cutting of the veggies small and roasting them. It will cause them to burn. Just mash them into the soup so you can puree it later.

Chef John never steers me wrong! I did read the comments and made roasted the veggies for less time than the squash. Also added an apple and the vinegar to taste. Very delicious, although a little time consuming. Will make again.
I absolutely LOVE this recipe; takes a little time, but well worth it. Lovely flavors, brended beautifully. Thanks for another winner, Chef John!!
Not a lot of work for a whole lot of flavour!
My very favorite go to butternut squash soup recipe!
I made this recipe and omg it turned out amazing. My husband asked me what is that amazing smell, I wasn't sure he would like it but it was love at first taste. I will be making it again!!!
good, but not what i was expecting

Made this to the letter, but there’s something missing. Maybe cumin or something with a little bite to add some complexity to the flavor, the apple cider vinegar’s not doing it for me. 

I also think it would have been more cohesive with a vegetable stock instead of chicken broth, chicken flavor is overwhelming the delicacy of the butternut squash.

I find this soup to be nicely balanced. The squash and carrots can be cloyingly sweet. The cayenne and vinegar and aromatics counter the sweetness nicely. My problem is that the vegetables tend to burn being in a 400 degree oven for an hour. Anyone else have this issue? Could be my roasting pan. It’s calphalon, but maybe the dark bottom has a tendency to burn things more?

The BEST soup ever! Family and neighbors raved over the flavor and entire batch was gone before it cooked. Sautéed the vegetables in sauce pan and added to roasted squash later. Roasted squash at 400 degrees for 50 minutes, flipped and added 2 tbsp butter and 2 tbsp brown sugar to each halve and roasted for another 20 minutes and then scooped out and into stew pot. The extra flavor was enjoyed by all. Wife asked me to make more so she cooked freeze it. Fantastic soup
Definitely one of the best soups I've ever made! Chef John has never let me down
BEST Butternut Squash Soup I’ve ever tasted

LOVE this, and have made it multiple times. Agree with several other reviewers that the vinegar is best left out, however. Some sour cream or creme fraiche can be added at the end for a little hit of acid.

I've made this at least half a dozen times now and while the original recipe is good, I've made a few tweaks to make it perfect! I sautee the onion and garlic while I roast JUST the butternut squash in the oven. When I throw everything in the stock pot, I throw in a sweet potato as well. I double the maple syrup, and do lemon instead of vinegar. Lemon lends acidity without being super apparent like vinegar. Yum!

I've made this more than a few times, following the instructions as given, but usually doubling the ingredients to make a double batch. Some for me, some to share. It has always been a conversation starter. Delicious, creamy and colorful. If you are making squash soup for the first time, make this one. it will be worth the effort.

Made per recipe except.... Used apple cider vinegar instead & only 1 tsp, 7 cups water, did not strain- blended the heck out of it with immersion hand blender, added a dash of nutmeg & cubed squash to roast. It is fantastic, smooth, sweet with hints of maple syrup & nutmeg and a buttery roasted aftertaste. Will definitely make again!

I made this yesterday and we loved it !! I didn't have any fresh sage so used the bottled . At first I didn't add the apple cider vinegar or maple syrup because it was so good without it. I tried it in my bowl it enhanced the flavor so added it to the pot !! I am going to make another batch to freeze .
Easy to make! Delicious!

Yummy.
Personal preference: WAY too much garlic. Overpowered all.
Will make this often with 1 clove garlic.
Delicious! I did not add apple cider vinegar or cream. It didn't need it.
Very different butternut squash soup. More savory than I’ve ever had. My husband doesn’t like the more sweet version, but he did like this one. It was a nice change of pace.
I had to add some Tajin chili and lime seasoning to add a little zing to this!

Super similar to my own recipe. I roasted the carrots and onion while in their skins along with the squash. Instead of apple cider vinegar, I used about a 1/2 cut of applesauce in it, then at serving swirled in a little balsamic vinegar along with the cream and a little EVOO. I skipped the maple syrup and used about a table spoon of fresh grated nutmeg. In it as well.
This is decadent. I did not add the vinegar, per other comments. That was a good choice. I used sour cream instead of creme fraiche. I served this with some crusty garlic bread.
I see other people didn't add the vinegar. I just want you to know, I did add the vinegar and I think the vinegar is what gives it the flavor that makes it so delicious. Just saying.
Good soup! I used curry powder instead of cayenne and skipped the vinegar per other reviewers. Served with creme fraiche and pepitas. Yum!!

The soup is phenomenal!
I made these adjustments:
I added (2) apples to the roasting vegetables and deleted the vinegar.
I reduced the maple syrup and added black strap molasses to enhance the smokiness.
I will make this again.

I was given some squash from a friends garden, so I was looking for a way to use them other than just cooking them alone. This recipe was great according to thise that ate it, because I don't care for any type of squash. Followed Chef John's recipe the first time, but only as a guide the second time.

Loved the sage butter and idea to strain it. I always go to Chef John’s version first. This time, I did add 1 small apple to the recipe and some celery because I have a lot on hand right now. I meal-prepped the roasted veggies last night so today I sautéed the onion, prepped the butter and added all to my insta-pot to cook for 30 minutes under pressure before blending and straining. Wonderful soup.
A bit time consuming, but good. I left out the apple cider vinegar based on other reviews. I also should have blended it longer b/c there were a few bits of onion fiber that were unappealing.

Delicious, I didnt strain it, I like the fiber.
Added the few thyme sprigs as suggested by another, very good. left out the Vinegar, used apple cider instead. It was awesome.

By golly this was good! We enjoyed smelling the roasting veggies, it was pretty to look at, loved the smooth thick texture, and then the taste! All those flavors melded into glory! The only divergence I did was using garam masala instead of cayenne...I was going for that rounder earthy taste instead of the sharpness.

This soup was delicious. The only thing I did differently was omit the garlic (yeah, yeah, I don't like garlic), add a little nutmeg and a bit of cayenne. It was perfect. This will definitely be a go-to soup for me.
Delicious
Wonderful ! I made it to spec...perfect...

My favourite soup now, it's so nice served with a slice of buttered toast. 

I made it a couple times and found that it was easier to peel the squash with a potato peeler before roasting in the oven... I feel you get more squash out of the deal that way and it's easier to chop and add to the soup after. Also halved the vinegar...
I have never had or made butternut squash soup until I tried this recipe. It is delicious! Well worth the time it takes to make it. Will continue to make in the future. Highly recommend it. :-)
Just amazing
I left out all sweet ingredients for a savory soup.

This is such a perfect recipe! I have made this a number of times and always turned out amazing and fit for company. I used the precut butternut squash from Costco. Just dumped those on the roasting pan with the onion and carrots cut up similar in size for even roasting. Then, added the garlic, drizzled the olive oil and roasted for an hour. Instead of an immersion blender at the end, I poured it all into my Vitamix blender on soup setting and it came out perfect, creamy and smooth.

EPIC soup! The only change I recommend is doubling the garlic and sage leaves and, like other reviews, omit the apple cider vinegar. For personal preference I also increased the amount of cayenne pepper. The flavors are very complex and perfectly balanced. Soooo delicious!!!
Yum ! Chef John score again.

This makes for a very tasty soup. I was not able to follow the recipe exactly since I didn't have all the ingredients and due to some of my forgetfulness. Half way through the roasting, I added half a red pepper with the vegetables. I forgot to brown the butter since I didn't have fresh sage. I had used dry thyme on the roasting veggies. I made a broth from the bottom of the roasting pan after removing the veggies. I didn't bother to strain the soup. I omitted the creme fraiche since I didn't have any, but I don't think it needed it either. My husband thought it was a great soup too, and that is saying a lot for someone who is picky about soups.

It was delicious eventually... However, the squash was still hard as a rock after an hour. Maybe because I used a roasting pan with high sides? Anyway, after baking it more, nuking it a few times, it was finally tender enough. It tasted great following Chef John's recipes.
This is my favorite butternut squash soup recipe. The sage infused butter make the flavor so rich. Roasting the squash is the only way to go.

The only change I made was that I had peeled and cut my butternut squash before I found the recipe. So I just added the cut squash to the onions, carrots and garlic and roasted as directed. I also had homemade chicken stock that I used. I will definitely make this recipe again. My guests asked me for the recipe also, which I was happy to share.

Chef John has become synonymous with delicious and well written recipes! This is no exception. My husband and I love squash soup and I am always searching for creative and tasty new ways to prepare it. This surprised because it was so simple yet created such a wonderful blend of flavors. I didn't roast the vegetables, because I was using thanksgiving leftover squash. I simply sautéed the onions and carrots until they just started to brown then added the squash and crushed garlic, the remaining ingredients! I can't wait to make this in a cold winter day when I have the time to roast the vegetables as called for. Thank you Chef John for another great recipe!

The brown butter made a huge difference! Straining the soup was much harder than it showed on the video - it took me a good 10-15 minutes and sore arms but this step made the soup velvety smooth. Loved how it turned out!
Easy and delicious - will definitely make again!

Made this for Thanksgiving last year instead of appetizers. Everyone loved it and I felt better for serving something healthy! I'll be making it again this year, but I don't have fresh butternut squash from my garden - I'll have to use store bought. I hope it turns out just as good...
I added a little nutmeg for extra flavor.
Only changes I made were omitted the apple cider vinegar and added one chopped granny Smith apple to roasted veggies and dressed each bowl with a balsamic reduction and fried sage leaves.

Made this exactly as it was written, and it was fabulous! I garnished it with toasted Pepitas & sour cream instead of crime fraiche. My husband, who hates squash, absolutely loved it and said it was one of his favorite soups I’ve ever made! Next time I think o will cut up the squash into chunks before roasting because it was too hot to scoop it out, and I think getting more carmelization on the squash would make it even better! This recipe is definitely a keeper.

I've made this twice and both times it has turned out so wonderfully. It definitely has a gorgeous autumnal sweet flavour with a bit of heat from the cayenne and tang from the vinegar. I would suggest going for a larger more middle-aged butternut for this recipe rather than a young, early season butternut. The second time I made this the butternut was slightly underripe and it was quite difficult to scoop the flesh away from the skin without the whole squash breaking apart. Otherwise I would say you can make it exactly as written without any issues. 

I didn't have creme fraiche so I subbed in some full-fat sour cream and it was delish. Happy souping!
My first time making this soup. It was great exactly as written. I only used a splash of apple cider vinegar because I was nervous after reading some other reviews. It turned out great!

Delicious flavor and great consistency. The sage butter adds a great note. I also added a sliced tart apple to the roasting pan. However--I know vinegar. I love vinegar. But 2 tablespoons is a lot to add all at once. I would suggest adding a teaspoon at a time to taste. I probably ended up using closer to one tablespoon. Two would have killed it. I would definitely make this again and again.

After reading a bunch of reviews I decide to make it my own and followed the vegetable ratios generally and the spices mostly.
I added a few celery sticks that had seen better days and didn't measure the carrots. Just chopped up 3 medium sized ones. I had a couple sweet potatoes in the fridge peeled and in need of something to be done with them so they got chopped and added to the pan!
I've decide that next time (and there will be!) I will peel the squash prior to roasting as my hands don't work well and I found it harder to scrape the squash out of the skin than to peel it raw.
I went out and bought some maple syrup to give this a true chance and was a little on the fence about the cider vinegar.
After straining the soup, which I left on the thick side I decided to sample the leftovers in the strainer with cider and added it 1/8th of a teaspoon at a time to the bowl.
Without the cider vinegar, I thought it was a little on sweet side and wasn't too sure of how I felt about a whole pot of it. After the cider added I thought that while I liked it some better it was missing something.
I added salt & pepper and it still was a little shy of great. I went back to the recipe and realized that I hadn't added any cayenne pepper. I sprinkled some on, mixed it in and finished off the bowl of soup. The cayenne pulled it all together and I can't wait for the creme fraiche to be ready and try it again!
This is a recipe that I would serve to friends and will be making fairly regularly this
Followed the recipe exactly except I substituted onion greens for the chives. Everybody loved it, even my husband who thinks he doesn’t like squash. This is definitely a recipe I’ll be making again.
I've made this as posted and it is perfect as it is. My picky wife plants lots of butternut every year so I can make lots of this for everyone in the family...

Would absolutely make this soup again— very hearty and savory!! One of the ingredients for success was the nutty sage brown butter— I threw in the buttered sage leaves in the soup (as in the video)! I did as suggested and put the soup through a sieve..... also blended it in a blender— same consistency, and the blender was easier . I did not add the cider vinegar— just made it last night, so will have some today—may try it with the vinegar.... will see which one selection I like best!
Absolutely scrumptious! Used ingredients as measured— came out to 12 cups of soup.
I did not put in onion. I used onion powder instead. I will make it again. Loved it!!!
made several versions from AllRecipies - and this is by far the best. I did add some cloves and pumpkin spice, as well as a bit of cream at the end to my taste, but as directed was very good as well.
Simply outstanding flavour, very easy to make. Takes a couple of hours but well worth the time. Perfect comfort food, so well balanced.
Oh So Good!! I thought I had a great Butternut Squash Soup recipe until my mother showed me this one!! Great with tea biscuits or savory scones!!

Super tasty, easy to make and very flavorful. The brown sage butter added a very nice touch! Made this soup with Toasted cheese sandwiches made using Sourdough bread, arugula, apricot preserves, provolone, swiss and a sprinkling of chives inside. Finished with flake salt on both sides of bread.

It was a snowy day. I had a butternut squash and most of the ingredients. This soup is delicious. I can hardly wait to make it with all of the ingredients. Changes of necessity this time were dried sage instead if fresh, and for the first time in forever I didn't have fresh garlic! I used 1/2 tsp of garlic powder added to the broth stage. Also added just 1 tsp if the Apple cider vinegar per other posts. I didn't have a strainer course enough but the texture was still smooth. Also the squash needed more roasting than the onions would tolerate so had to separate them early. will definitely make this again. Thank you again, Chef John.
So yummy and easy, I diced the squash and had to use my blender but it is Yummy!!!!!

We had an overabundance of butternut squash in our garden this year, so this recipe was a life saver for preserving the good bounty of the garden! I made A LOT of this soup and canned it- it is delicious! Pureed everything in my vitamix, so it is super smooth. It is great to pair with some homemade rolls or bread for a warm winter meal. I have never added the creme fraiche, and think it is perfectly fine without it. Would just make it more elegant- because it is still superb without the extra creme. Will be making it next fall if our squash does well again. I'm looking forward to it!
We have made it over and over again. Haven't changed a thing. Inspired us to grow our own butternut squash!

A wonderful recipe. The only soup changes I made were to add 1/2-2/3 of the suggested amounts of broth, syrup and vinegar and adjusted to taste after simmering (thanks to previous reviews!). My husband crumbled bacon and I fried more sage leaves in butter (meatless Monday) & crumbled over sour cream dollops.
easy to make and taste great
chef john, it was delicious. the only change I made was to add an apple. you rock chef john....

As usual, when I make a recipe it is revised due to not enough this or that. I had only 1 small onion so I added some leftover boiled potato & a few chopped up celery sticks. The directions didn't say whether to keep the sage leaves or remove so I pureed them into the batch. More chicken stock required (1L) and fresh ground pepper. Voila another butchered recipe that turned out tasting excellent. And yes, I'll do it again. Cheesy baking powder biscuits made this recipe a must-do-again for our current, chilly Cariboo weather.

Best butternut squash soup I have ever had. The sage butter really make this dish. A perfect Fall soup. 

I find it easier to peel the butternut squash first, before roasting it. Once it comes out of the oven, it's hot and takes a long time to cool down enough to handle. I don't have that kind of patience, and scooping hot roasted squash out of the skin is about as fun as it sounds.
It was too sweet.
I have made squash soup before, but this recipe is definitely the much tastier version. The sage-infused brown butter was really cool!
This is the best butternut squash soup recipe I have ever made. You can totally eliminate the creme fraiche if you are dairy free... It's rich and delicious..

This is my new favorite soup. I almost followed the recipe exactly. As I was roasting the veggies, I noticed everything but the squash was done much sooner than the squash, so I pulled it out and left the squash in. I am glad I did. I missed one piece of onion and it was very burned. I also forgot to add the vinegar at the end. I don't know that I missed it. I thought this was terrific without.
This soup is delicious. Made it just like recipe with the exception I only had red onions. Was so aromatic and tasty with them.
It's SO GOOD!!!!! Super easy to make. And it tastes too good to be true.

Oh my goodness, this was delicious! I omitted the apple cider vinegar and cayenne pepper, as other reviewers suggested. It did not need it whatsoever. I topped it with a few goat cheese crumbles and crouton pieces for a crunch. I’ll be making this each time I get a butternut squash and carrots in my CSA box for sure!

I have many good butternut squash soup recipes but this is definitely the best. I made it exactly as demonstrated (There seems to be a couple of details missing from the written instructions.) I used sour cream but will make creme fraiche the next time.
We loved it and there was no leftovers

I'm not exagerating at all when I say this is one of the most amazing soups I have ever tasted. We recently started a diet with no wheat, soy, sugar or pork. We were only on day two when I fixed this. I used sour cream instead of creme fraiche but that was my only tweak. My sweetie said it was the best soup he has ever tasted. It is rich and hearty and we have enjoyed it for two days since. I will be making this often, especially as fall and winter approach.

wow. just wow. worth the cooking times. 
I made everything as written except I needed to sub ground sage for fresh sage - I'm sure there'd be a richer profile with the fresh but honestly, this was so good that I would do it again this way. 
after the blending, I omitted the apple cider (because I didn't have it, and other reviewers said it wasn't necessary - and I agree. full depth of flavor without it!) and instead of creme fraiche, i put in a dollop of nonfat greek yogurt. 
delish! very filling.
Excellent and my son loved it too
My new favorite soup!!!
I liked it. I added extra carrots. It is good. I would put in less syrup.
One of the best soups I have ever made. So tasty, the family devoured it.

Very good! I had never made squash before so I dont know if I properly cooked them, since it was hard to get off the skin. Didnt have sage so I used some fresh rosemary. (Also doubled the butter because I hate my heart). If I had smoked salt would have used that.

Overall amazing. This will enter my rotation of weekly soups.
Just made it and it was wonderful! Made some fresh rye bread to go with it and it was the perfect meal.

It was ok, but added some brown sugar to sweeten it up a bit.
Not sure if I'll make it again

It was ok, but added some brown sugar to sweeten it up a bit.
Not sure if I'll make it again
I made it as written and it was delicious!

We loved this! Thank you Chef John! I loved the roasted veggies that added another layer of flavor. This is now my go to recipe for Butternut squash. I have made it with the vinegar and without both are good but my hubby prefers no vinegar. This is a keeper.

item.name: Chef John's Roasted Butternut Squash Soup
